resources.string: Kata laluan mesti lebih kurang daripada 5 aksara

Explanation:- Americans might casually say this when asking someone to move slightly, but those who aren\'t familiar with the term can be forgiven for not having a clue what the American is asking them to do.
Explanation:- When directly translated, this American phrase sounds to a non-English speaker that the speaker is wishing them ill will or putting some kind of curse on them.

\"Explanation:- Sort of the opposite of break a leg, this expression, said (and done) when someone hopes something happens or continues to happen is common throughout the English speaking world (usually as touch wood outside America). \"
Explanation:- it\'s not rocket science is a way of explaining something by hyperbolically explaining what it\'s not—in this case, saying something is not too difficult.
Explanation:- When we want to get change, turning a larger bill into smaller ones, this term can come in handy.
Explanation:- When you say to table something you mean to shelve it. When I say to table something I mean to put it on the table for discussion.
Explanation:- to mend, or repair something clumsily.
Explanation:- Would you like a cup of tea?
Slang:- Aikona – not on your life
Explanation:- This is the Afrikaans equivalent to “Oh man!” and is often used at the beginning of a sentence to express pity, resignation or irritation.
Explanation:- A Zulu term used to express shock or disbelief when talking to friends or family.
Explanation:- This term is usually used in reference to a male friend or companion.
Explanation:- This term is commonly used to call a friend, pal or buddy.
Explanation:- Often used when talking about food, this term can be used as a verb, meaning to eat, or when talking about the food itself.
Explanation:- Usually expressed when someone experiences a sharp pain of some sort.
Slang:- Ulu (ooh-loo) / out of the way
Slang:- Kancheong Spider (kun-chee-ong-spider) / jittery or nervous
Explanation:- In tiny Singapore, any place that requires more than an hour to get to by public transport, or is particularly hard to find, can be considered ‘so ulu’.
Explanation:- If someone asks you whether they ‘can tompang?’, they are usually asking you to give them a lift somewhere, or to help them pass an item to someone else.
Explanation:- This Malay term can be used to describe food (‘makan!’) or the action of having a meal (as in ‘let’s go makan’).
Explanation:- The Singaporean way of ‘chope-ing’ something is most commonly seen in hawker centres, with tissue packets indicating that the table is taken.
Explanation:- Someone calling you a ‘kancheong spider’ is basically saying that you need to chill out and not be so nervous about things.

Explanation:- A Chinese Hokkien term that translates literally as ‘eating strength’, this is a multi-purpose phrase you can use to exclaim about most things bad – whether it’s a person, behaviour or circumstance.
Slang:- My bloody car carked it yesterday.
Slang:- Mandy is packing a sad.
Explanation:- Pass me the chewing gum.
Slang:- Bonzour. Mo appel…, kouma ou apele?
Slang:- Azordi, mo finn fer letour lil.
Slang:- Ki dernie pri ou kapav fer ?
Slang:- Alo, mo kapav koz ek…?
Explanation:- Hello. My name is… What is your name?
Explanation:- Today, I toured the island.
Explanation:- Can you lower the price?
Explanation:- Hello, may I speak to…?
Explanation:- An adventure in Italy done right will leave you with plenty of chances to use and hear, What a cool thing!.
Explanation:- Its translation means less bad, but it’s used like, Thank God!
Explanation:- The Italian counterpart to I wish!, Let’s hope!, or Maybe!

Explanation:- In just about every conversation, yaar is a recurring slang term that’s used in casual social interactions between friends and sometimes even strangers who may be shopkeepers or autorickshaw drivers.
Explanation:- Used to express I see, okay, or really?
Explanation:- Whether at a lunch table or on a cab ride, bas is used when someone needs to communicate “that will be all.”

Explanation:- The meaning of this term changes with intonation. When used in a higher tone, it expresses surprise. In a lower tone, it conveys exasperation. Said neutrally, it’s used to get attention.
Explanation:- This term is especially popular among college students who use it in the context of ideas.
Explanation:- Jugaad is a popular term used in response to someone looking for a solution.
Explanation:- This is the slang word Colombians use for referring to a friend.
Explanation:- Want to say something is really good or cool? Don’t limit yourself to saying that it is muy bueno and instead go for one of these two hugely popular local terms.
Explanation:- Rumba is technically a sort of music/dance originating in Cuba, but in Colombia it invariably means a party. Rumbear is to go partying.
Explanation:- Here it means something like: a group of friends getting together to do something.
Explanation:- Harto is a common term meaning a lot of or a ton of.
Explanation:- An enthusiastic way to say yes, absolutely!
Explanation:- This word is used in everyday Canadian vernacular to indicate that you don’t understand something, can’t believe something is true or want the person you’re speaking with to respond.
Explanation:- This bad boy is a Tim Hortons favorite: regular coffee with two creams and two sugars.
Explanation:- The 6ix refers to the six former cities that now make up Toronto.
Explanation:- This term is commonly used to refer to a case of 24 beers. Don’t be surprised when a friend asks you to pick one up on the way over.
Explanation:- A mickey is a hip-flask-size bottle of liquor. You can only find these at the LCBO. It fits perfectly in your purse, pocket or hand.
Explanation:- Refers to soda, the delicious carbonated beverage that mom rarely lets you have.
Explanation:- E aí? is quite a colloquial way of saying hi. It’s pretty much like saying what’s up? in English.
\"Explanation:- The word bacana means good or awesome. \"
Explanation:- A loose translation for tá bom? is all good? It’s a way of asking if someone agrees or is okay with a proposition.
Explanation:- Cara is colloquially used to mean face but it’s also slang used to talk about a guy or a man.
Explanation:- In English, someone might say My bad! when they’ve made an obvious blunder.
Explanation:- A colloquial verb that’s best translated as to get out.
Slang:- No worries, mate, she\'ll be right
Slang:- Put a sock in it
Slang:- Wrap your laughing gear \'round that
Explanation:- Reflects a national stoicism that suggests everything (she) will turn out fine in the end. This being the case, there\'s no real point in worrying about anything.
Explanation:- Someone playing a good game of sport (having a blinder), or something that\'s exceptionally good. Can also be bonza or beaut.
Explanation:- When Julia Gillard was voted in as the country\'s first female prime minister, it didn\'t take long for Australia to start calling the prime minister\'s partner the first bloke.
Explanation:- Euphemisms used to communicate amazement or surprise.
Explanation:- Tells somebody to shut up.
Explanation:- While some suggest you can laugh on the inside, your main laughing gear is your mouth. So when you wrap your laughing gear \'round something, you eat it.
Tekan kembali sekali lagi untuk keluar dari aplikasi
